```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  collapse = TRUE,
  echo = TRUE
)
```


Huxtable is a package for creating HTML and LaTeX tables. It provides similar 
functionality to xtable, but does a lot more, with a simpler interface. Here's a quick example.


```{r, echo = TRUE, results = 'asis'}
library(huxtable)

ht <- huxtable(a = 1:5, b = letters[1:5])
align(ht)[,2] <- 'right'
background_color(ht) <- 'wheat'
bottom_border(ht) <- c(1, 0, 0, 0, 1)
to_html(ht)
```


Or the same thing with a more dplyr-ish syntax:

```{r, echo = TRUE, results = 'asis'}
library(huxtable)
library(dplyr)

ht <- hux(a = 1:5, b = letters[1:5]) %>% 
      set_align(1:5, 2, 'right') %>% 
      set_background_color(1, , 'wheat') %>% 
      set_bottom_border(1:5, 1:2, c(1, 0, 0, 0, 1))

to_html(ht)
```


To learn more, check out the vignette in [HTML] or [PDF] or the original [R Markdown](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hughjonesd/huxtable/master/vignettes/introduction-to-huxtable.Rmd).
